use_ancestral_state.comment: <text lang="en">Give a ancestors file whenever you enable this parameter</text> </comment>

format.python: ln -s " + str( ancestors_file ) + " ancestors")[ value is not None ]

ancestors_file.comment: <text lang="en">The A (Ancestral states) option. This indicates that we are specifying the ancestral states for each character.</text> <text lang="en">In the menu the ancestors (A) option must be selected. An ancestral states input file is read, whose default name is ancestors.</text> <text lang="en">It contains a line or lines giving the ancestral states for each character. These may be 0, 1 or ?</text> <text lang="en">the latter indicating that the ancestral state is unknown.</text> <text lang="en">An example is: 001??11</text> <text lang="en">The ancestor information can be continued to a new line and can have blanks between any of the characters in the same way that species character data can.</text> </comment>

parsimony_method.comment: <text lang="en">Only if Use Mixed method is disabled.</text> </comment>

use_mixed.comment: <text lang="en">Give a mixure file whenever you choose Mixed method</text> </comment>

format.python: ln -s " + str( mixture_file ) + " mixture")[ value is not None ]

mixture_file.comment: <text lang="en">The X (miXture) option. Move, and Penny the user can specify for each character which parsimony method is in effect.</text> <text lang="en">This is done by selecting menu option X (not M) and having an input mixture file . It contains a line or lines with and one letter for each character.</text> <text lang="en">These letters are C or S if the character is to be reconstructed according to Camin-Sokal parsimony, W or ? if the character is to be reconstructed according to Wagner parsimony.</text> <text lang="en">So if there are 20 characters the line giving the mixture might look like this:</text> <text lang="en">WWWCC WWCWC</text> <text lang="en">Note that blanks in the sequence of characters (after the first ones that are as long as the species names) will be ignored, and the information can go on to a new line at any point. So this could equally well have been specified by</text> <text lang="en">WW</text> <text lang="en">CCCWWCWC</text> </comment>

data_nb.comment: <text lang="en">If you choose Analyze multiple data sets, you must indicate the number of sets you have.</text> </comment>

precond.python: ( jumble_or_dataset is not None ) and ( jumble_or_dataset == "J" )
( jumble_or_dataset is not None ) and ( jumble_or_dataset == "D" )

format.perl:
"M
D
" + str( data_nb ) + "
" + str( seed ) +"
" + str( times ) +"
"
format.python:
"M
D
" + str( data_nb ) + "
" + str( seed ) +"
" + str( times ) +"
"

user_tree.prompt: Use User tree (default: search for best tree) (U)
user_tree.comment: <text lang="en">The user-defined trees supplied if you use the U option must be given as rooted trees with two-way splits (bifurcations)</text> </comment>

format.python: ln -s " + str( tree_file ) + " intree")[ value is not None ]

tree_file.comment: <text lang="en">Give a tree whenever the infile does not already contain the tree.</text> </comment>

tree_number.prompt: How many tree(s) in the User Tree file
tree_number.comment: <text lang="en">Give this information whenever the infile does not already contain the tree.</text> </comment>

print_tree.comment: <text lang="en">Tells the program to print a semi-graphical picture of the tree in the outfile.</text> </comment>

print_step.prompt: Print out steps in each character (4)

print_states.prompt: Print states at all nodes of tree (5)

print_treefile.prompt: Write out trees onto tree file (6)
print_treefile.comment: <text lang="en">Tells the program to save the tree in a treefile (a standard representation of trees where the tree is specified by a nested pairs of parentheses, enclosing names and separated by commas).</text> </comment>

printdata.prompt: Print out the data at start of run (1)

format.python: ( "" , "O\n" + str( value ) + "\n" )[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment: <text lang="en">MIX is a general parsimony program which carries out the Wagner and Camin-Sokal parsimony methods in mixture, where each character can have its method specified separately. The program defaults to carrying out Wagner parsimony.</text> </comment>
